pageContext.description:
## **AF Emory Agenda (revised February 19)**
Location: Jones Room, Woodruff Library
## **DAY 1**
8:30 – 9:00 am
- Registration and Coffee
9:00 – 9:15 am
- Welcome
### **Session 1: Led by Dr. Tina Herzberg**
9:15 – 9:45 am: Lecture
- Philip M. Ferguson, Emily Nusbaum, “[Disability Studies: What Is It?](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/78362125.pdf)”, _Research & Practice for Persons with Severe Disabilities_ (2012) Vol. 37, No. 2, 70-80.
- Jonathan Lazar, Paul Jaeger, “[Reducing Barriers to Online Access for People with Disabilities,](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/57458148.pdf),” _Issues in Science and Technology_(Winter 2011), 69-82.
9:45 – 10:15 am
- Group Activity: Defining Accessibility for oneself. What is your personal definition?
### **Session 2: Led by Dan Brown, Humanware**
10:15 – Noon: Demonstration: Accessible Hardware for Disabled Users
- Kessler Foundation and National Organization on Disability, “The ADA 20 Years Later: An Executive Summary,” July 2010.[ Available here](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.2010disabilitysurveys.org/pdfs/surveysummary.pdf)
Noon- 12:45 pm: Lunch
### **Session 3: Led by Dr. George Williams**
12:45 – 1:45 pm: Lecture and Discussion
- George H. Williams, “Disability, Universal Design, and the Digital Humanities,” _Debates in Digital Humanities_. University of Minnesota Press.[ Available here](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://dhdebates.gc.cuny.edu/debates/text/44)
1:45-2 pm: Break
### **Session 4: Led by Dr. Jennifer Guiliano**
2:00 – 2:30 pm: Cognitive Disabilities and the Web
- “Evaluating Cognitive Web Accessibility,” _Web Accessibility Initative_ [WebAIMhttp://webaim.org/articles/cognitive/cognitive\_too\_little/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://webaim.org/articles/cognitive/cognitive_too_little/)
The presentation on cognitive disabilities and the web is available in PDF form. [Cognitive Lecture Accessible Future](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/Cognitive-Lecture-Accessible-Future.pdf)
2:30 – 3:00 pm: Deafness, deafness, and accessibility
- “Deafness and the User Experience,” by Lisa Herrod[http://alistapart.com/article/deafnessandtheuserexperience](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://alistapart.com/article/deafnessandtheuserexperience)
The presentation on Deafness, deafness, and accessibility is available in PDF form. [Deafness and Accessibility](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/Deafness-and-Accessibility.pdf)
### **Session 5: Led by Dr. George Williams and Jeremy Boggs**
3:00 – 4:30 pm: Evaluating Web Accessibility
- “How People with Disabilities Use the Web,” _Web Accessibility Initiative._[ Available here](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.w3.org/WAI/intro/people-use-web/)
- “Considering the User Perspective: A Summary of Design Issues,” _Web Accessibility Initiative_[WebAIM](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://webaim.org/articles/userperspective/)
- [http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200709/10\_colour\_contrast\_checking\_tools\_to\_improve\_the\_accessibility\_of\_your\_design/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200709/10_colour_contrast_checking_tools_to_improve_the_accessibility_of_your_design/)
- Browser add ons to simulate color blindness types, e.g.[ https://addons.mozilla.org/eN-US/firefox/addon/colorblind-design/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/https://addons.mozilla.org/eN-US/firefox/addon/colorblind-design/)
- Google Chrome Accessibility Tools:[https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/accessibility-developer-t/fpkknkljclfencbdbgkenhalefipecmb?hl=en](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/accessibility-developer-t/fpkknkljclfencbdbgkenhalefipecmb?hl=en)
Either use the[ WAVE web page interface](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://wave.webaim.org/), or download and install the[ WAVE Toolbar for Firefox](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://wave.webaim.org/toolbar/).
- The WAVE Firefox toolbar provides a mechanism for running WAVE accessibility reports directly within Firefox.
(See also “[Web Accessibility Evaluation Tools: Overview](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.w3.org/WAI/ER/tools/).”)
Please also explore Pa11y, the automated accessibility testing system ([http://pa11y.org/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://pa11y.org/)) and HTML\_Codesniffer: [http://squizlabs.github.io/HTML\_CodeSniffer/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://squizlabs.github.io/HTML_CodeSniffer/)
Small Group activity: Evaluation and discussion of a number of online resources, including the following:
- [The Shakespeare Quartos Archive](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.quartos.org/)
- [The William Blake Archive](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.blakearchive.org/)
- [The Bracero History Archive](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://braceroarchive.org/)
- [Cornell University Library: Making of America](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://ebooks.library.cornell.edu/m/moa/)
- [Visualizing Emancipation](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://dsl.richmond.edu/emancipation/)
- [Deaf Studies Digital Journal](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://dsdj.gallaudet.edu/)
- [Nineteenth-Century Disability: A Digital Reader](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.nineteenthcenturydisability.org/)
- [BrailleSC.org](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://braillesc.org/)
### **Session 6: Led by Jeremy Boggs**
4:30 – 5 pm: Integrating accessibility testing into the workflow of projects and workplaces
## **Day 2**
Please note the doors to the library do not open until 9 am.
9:15 – 9:30 am Coffee
### **Session 7: Led by Jeremy Boggs**
9:30 –10:30 am: HTML and CSS Concepts
- Peterson, “[Accessibility in HTML5](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.clarissapeterson.com/2012/11/html5-accessibility/)”
- [HTML5 Accessibility](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://html5accessibility.com/)
- [Webplatform.org](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.webplatform.org/)
View the session information: [http://clioweb.github.io/accessiblefuture/](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://clioweb.github.io/accessiblefuture/)
### **Session 8: Led by Jeremy Boggs and James Smith**
10:30 –11:30 am: Hands On with HTML and CSS to Address Accessibility Issues
11:30 –11:45 am: Break
12:50 – 1:30: Continuing with HTML and CSS this time talking about responsive design
### **Session 9: Led by James Smith**
1:30 – 2:30 pm: WordPress
- [WordPress Codex Accessibility](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/WordPress-Codex-Accessibility.pdf)
- [WordPress Accessibility Plugin](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.accessiblefuture.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2013/09/WP-Accessibility-Plugin.pdf)
- [W3C Accessibility Standards](https://web.archive.org/web/20150220061132/http://www.w3.org/standards/webdesign/accessibility)
### **Session 10: Led by George Williams and Tina Herzberg**
2:30 – 3:15 pm: Encouraging/soliciting feedback from users with accessibility concerns
3:15 – 3:30 pm break
### **Session 11: Led by Jennifer Guiliano**
3:30 – 4 pm: Advocating for Accessibility on your campus by creating an Accessibility Statement
